control.control_purpose: To ensure all system clocks are synchronised to approved time sources enabling correlation and analysis of security-related events and support for incident investigations
control.control_objective: Maintain accurate and consistent time across all information processing systems enabling temporal correlation of events and forensic analysis of security incidents

iso_27001_definition.official_text: The clocks of information processing systems used by the organisation should be synchronised to approved time sources.
key_requirements: Clocks of information processing systems synchronised
Consistency of time across all systems
Support for event correlation and analysis

control_purpose_detail.purpose: Detective control enabling temporal correlation of security events across multiple systems and supporting forensic investigation of security incidents
control_purpose_detail.key_outcome: Accurate correlation and sequencing of events enabling forensic analysis and investigation

required_prerequisites.description: Risk assessment identifying need for time synchronisation

required_prerequisites.description: Logging systems capable of recording accurate event timestamps

implementation_requirements.description: Identify legal, regulatory, contractual and operational requirements for time synchronisation

implementation_requirements.description: Choose appropriate time synchronisation protocol for organisation

Precision Time Protocol (PTP) - higher precision for critical systems
Simple Network Time Protocol (SNTP) - simplified NTP variant
protocol_selection: PTP for systems requiring sub-millisecond precision
GPS for systems requiring high accuracy and independence
Simple protocols acceptable for smaller organisations
Protocol must support required accuracy and reliability

Different device types may use different sources

Clock offset tolerances established and monitored

NTP/PTP clients on all systems requiring synchronisation
Network infrastructure supporting time protocol traffic

configuration_elements: Time server configured to receive approved time source

Alerts when time source becomes unavailable
Verification that time is advancing normally
acceptable_time_differences: Clock accuracy tolerance defined (typically within seconds)
Investigation and correction if drift detected

implementation_requirements.description: Maintain documentation of clock synchronisation approach and implementation

documentation_requirements: Policy or procedure documenting synchronisation requirements

documentation_maintenance: Documentation kept current as systems change

implementation_requirements.description: Address systems that cannot be synchronised to network time source

Some air-gapped systems may not have network access
managing_exceptions: Record known time differences for identified systems

testing_procedures: Verify time server is receiving and maintaining correct time
Verify client systems are synchronising to time server

common_mistakes.description: Top 3 mistakes organizations make with clock synchronisation

mistakes.description: Synchronising network servers and computers but overlooking physical security systems, surveillance systems, building access systems and other devices with clocks
root_cause: Assumption that only IT systems need synchronisation
Physical and security systems managed separately from IT
Lack of comprehensive planning across all departments
Physical systems not considered as information processing systems
mistakes.impact: Inability to correlate events across all systems for incident investigation, forensic evidence gaps, audit failures
prevention: Conduct comprehensive inventory of all devices with clocks
Include physical security systems in synchronisation planning
Coordinate between IT, physical security and other departments
Review entire organisation for clock-bearing devices

mistakes.mistake: Selecting unreliable or inaccessible time sources
mistakes.description: Choosing time sources that are unreliable, have poor accuracy or are not accessible from organisation's infrastructure
root_cause: Insufficient technical evaluation of time sources
Not considering redundancy or failover options
Selecting distant or unreliable internet NTP servers
mistakes.impact: Systems drift out of synchronisation, loss of time accuracy, inability to correlate events, failed incident investigations
prevention: Evaluate multiple time source options carefully
Test accessibility and accuracy before implementation

mistakes.mistake: Lack of monitoring and verification of synchronisation
mistakes.description: Implementing time synchronisation but not monitoring whether systems remain synchronised or detecting when synchronisation fails
root_cause: Assumption that synchronisation will work continuously
No monitoring implemented to verify operation
mistakes.impact: Systems drift out of synchronisation undetected, events recorded with inconsistent timestamps, incident investigation compromised
prevention: Implement monitoring to verify synchronisation status
Include synchronisation monitoring in incident response procedures
Conduct internal audits of synchronisation operation

ukgc_application.critical_systems_context: For gambling operators, accurate time synchronisation is critical for transaction integrity, regulatory compliance and incident investigation. UKGC expects that all times recorded for transactions, wagers and game outcomes are accurate and can be verified. Time synchronisation supports accurate regulatory reporting and enables investigation of disputes and suspected breaches.

Wager recording systems synchronised so game outcome verification is temporally consistent
Payment processing systems synchronised ensuring payment timestamps are reliable for reconciliation
Access control systems synchronised so access audit trails correlate with system activities
Game server clocks synchronised ensuring game outcome timestamps are accurate
Customer account access timestamps accurate for investigating unauthorised access claims
Surveillance and physical security systems synchronised enabling correlation with system events
All log timestamps traceable to synchronised time source
Time synchronisation sufficient to support UKGC investigation of disputes and allegations

gambling_operator_specific_guidance.transaction_timestamp_accuracy: For gambling operators, transaction timestamp accuracy is critical for dispute resolution and regulatory compliance. All customer transactions including wagers, payouts and account changes must be recorded with timestamps traceable to synchronised clocks. Timestamp accuracy should be sufficient to support millisecond-level precision for high-volume betting systems. Transaction timestamp accuracy must be verified through testing and audit.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.game_outcome_integrity: Game outcome timestamps recorded at the moment outcome is determined must be from synchronised clocks. This ensures game outcome verification can correlate outcome timestamp with corresponding wager timestamp and customer claim. Synchronised timestamps support demonstrating game integrity when disputes arise.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.payment_reconciliation: Payment system clocks must be synchronised to enable accurate reconciliation of transactions between internal systems, payment processors and customer accounts. Timestamp discrepancies can complicate reconciliation and must be avoided through clock synchronisation.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.access_audit_trails: Access to customer accounts, customer data and sensitive systems must be recorded with timestamps from synchronised clocks. This enables correlation of access audit trails with transaction logs to investigate suspicious access patterns.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.regulatory_reporting: All timestamps in regulatory reports must be traceable to synchronised clocks. Reports to UKGC must be able to demonstrate that reported timestamps are accurate and consistent.
gambling_operator_specific_guidance.audit_readiness: To be audit-ready for UKGC examination, gambling operators should: document clock synchronisation requirements and approved time source; implement synchronisation across all transaction and security systems; verify synchronisation is operating; demonstrate monitoring and testing; document how synchronisation supports incident investigation; and provide evidence of timestamp accuracy in sample logs and reports.
